fields.value: Replication Data for: Beyond Norms. A configurational analysis of the EU’s Arab Spring sanctions

dsDescriptionValue.value: This paper explores and explains the EU’s use of sanctions in response to the Arab Spring in 13 Middle East and North Africa (MENA) states. A Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA) shows that a combination of historical factors and human rights violations contributed to the EU’s decision to impose sanctions in Libya and Syria, while transitional void seems to have been the most important trigger for sanctions in Egypt and Tunisia. The absence of both transitional void and historical economic coercion, explain why the EU has refrained from imposing sanctions in negative cases such as Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. Exposing the complex causality of the EU’s Arab Spring sanctions, this paper nuances the EU’s self-proclaimed normative foreign policy approach and demonstrates that combinations of factors matter for explaining the EU’s decision to invoke sanctions in the MENA region.

files.description: Note that this file has been added for the sake of completeness. The data matrix included in this CSV file is also entered directly in the R file (data.frame command).
files.label: datfuzzy.tab

dataFile.description: Note that this file has been added for the sake of completeness. The data matrix included in this CSV file is also entered directly in the R file (data.frame command).

files.description: This file includes all commands needed to calibrate the uncalibrated data matrix and to replicate the paper's results (analysis of necessity and analysis of sufficiency). Tables 1 to 3 of the paper are replicated in the section 'analysis of sufficiency'.
files.label: R file.R

dataFile.description: This file includes all commands needed to calibrate the uncalibrated data matrix and to replicate the paper's results (analysis of necessity and analysis of sufficiency). Tables 1 to 3 of the paper are replicated in the section 'analysis of sufficiency'.
